Dear Sarah Codere:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Reevaluation
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12324
Section • (2) The annual reevaluation must include a determination
Description and assessment of all the following:
1

• (a) All changes to the factual information contained
in the initial evaluation and subsequent renewal
evaluations.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency has a foster home that moved approximately two years
ago, and they did not address the change of address in the recent
reevaluation of the home.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Licensing Supervisor who is also the Program Manager, was
interviewed via video conferencing on 6/5/2024. She reported the
family’s move was addressed in the most recently completed
renewal assessment, but the worker forgot to make the address
change in CWLM.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
-CWL-4004, Foster Home Reevaluation completed as a renewal
on 4/19/2024 which indicates there have been no changes to the
home and the address documented as the home that was
assessed is the same address in which the family has lived since
being licensed.
-Address change is documented in CWLM to have been 7/1/2022
Analysis The agency is in violation as the most recently completed renewal
report does not include the updated address of the family.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code License recommendation
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12325
Section • (2) An agency shall document foster home license changes
Description in the foster home record and communicate the changes
immediately to the department in the manner prescribed by
the department.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency has a foster home that moved approximately two years
ago, and they did not complete an addendum.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Licensing Supervisor, who is also the Program Manager, was
interviewed via video conferencing on 6/5/2024. She reported she
was the family’s assigned worker at the time the family began
talking about moving, which was sometime in the summer of
2022. Licensing Supervisor couldn’t recall exactly when the family
moved to a new home, but she believed in was in August or
September of 2022. She reported she did not have the family
2

complete a new application when they moved, did not assess the
new home for compliance with licensing rules, and did not
complete a relocation report. She reported she knew she was
supposed to do those things, and made some attempts to connect
with the family, but never did. She stated when Licensing Worker
was hired in October of 2022, Licensing Supervisor “passed this
off” to her. She stated Licensing Worker did visit and assess the
home in March of 2023, but she did not have the family sign a new
application or complete a relocation report at that time.
Licensing Worker was interviewed via video conferencing on
6/7/2024. She reported working at the agency since October of
2022. She stated she completed her training and was assigned
cases in mid to late December 2022. She stated Licensing
Supervisor had been attempting to schedule home visits with
Foster Parent A in November and December 2022, but Foster
Parent A is notoriously difficult to connect with due to the large
and busy family, so no visit was scheduled. Licensing Worker
reported she had a visit scheduled with Foster Parent A in
January of 2023, but the family got sick, so the visit was
cancelled. After multiple attempts to reschedule, Licensing Worker
was able to get to the home in March 2023. Licensing Worker
stated she gave Foster Parent A a new application during that
visit, but Foster Parent B was not home, so the application was
signed by both foster parents and returned in April 2023.
Licensing Worker stated she did not know what efforts were made
to complete a new application or assessment of the new home
prior to her hire. She stated she was not aware a relocation study
needed to be completed on the new home.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
-Provider Address Change in CWLM created 5/28/2024 and is
pending DCWL approval.
-Address change is documented in CWLM to have been 7/1/2022.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as it is documented the
family moved in July of 2022; however, a new application was not
obtained, a relocation study was not completed, nor was an
address change made to the provider record until 2024.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Reevaluation
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12324
Section • (1) An agency shall conduct an annual on-site visit and
Description complete a written reevaluation of a foster home.
3

Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Agency did not complete an annual assessment timely.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Licensing Supervisor, who is also the Program Manager, was
interviewed via video conferencing on 6/5/2024. She reported the
family’s annual assessment was due in October 2022 and she
made some attempts to connect with them to complete that
assessment but was unsuccessful, so she passed the task off to
Licensing Worker. She stated Licensing Worker was finally able to
connect with the family and schedule a home visit in March 2023.
Licensing Supervisor stated, since the annual assessment was
already overdue at that point, she advised Licensing Worker to
skip typing the 2022 annual assessment and complete the
renewal assessment in December 2023.
Licensing Worker was interviewed via video conferencing on
6/7/2024. She reported working at the agency since October
2022. She stated she completed her training and was assigned
cases in mid to late December 2022. She stated Licensing
Supervisor had been attempting to schedule home visits with
Foster Parent A in November and December 2022, but Foster
Parent A is notoriously difficult to connect with due to the large
and busy family, and no visit was scheduled. She reported she
had a visit scheduled with Foster Parent A in January 2023, but
the family got sick, so the visit was cancelled. After multiple
attempts to reschedule, Licensing Worker was able to get to the
home in March 2023. Licensing Worker stated the annual
assessment was already overdue at that point, so she put
everything into the next renewal report. She reported the family
hadn’t had a placement in over a year, so they aren’t active, which
is why she believed this was pushed to the back burner.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
- Active Licenses:
12/10/2021 – 12/9/2023
12/10/2023 – 12/9/2026
-CWL-4004, Foster Home Reevaluation due 12/2022 completed
as an Annual Assessment signed by worker and supervisor
2/6/2024.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as the annual assessment
due in 2022 was completed in April of 2024.
Conclusion Violation Established
4

Rule Code Reevaluation
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12324
Section • (8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and make a
Description licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The agency did not make a recommendation at least 15 days prior
to the license expiring.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Licensing Supervisor, who is also the Program Manager, was
interviewed via video conferencing on 6/5/2024. She reported
Licensing Worker had difficulty scheduling with the family as
Foster Parent A has a lot of high needs youths in the home, so
she is busy and isn’t good about returning calls.
Licensing Worker was interviewed via video conferencing on
6/7/2024. She stated Licensing Supervisor had been attempting to
schedule home visits with Foster Parent A in November and
December 2022, but Foster Parent A is notoriously difficult to
connect with due to the large and busy family, and no visit was
scheduled. She reported she had a visit scheduled with Foster
Parent A in January 2023, but the family got sick, so the visit was
cancelled. After multiple attempts to reschedule, Licensing Worker
was able to get to the home in March 2023.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
- Active Licenses:
12/10/2021 – 12/9/2023
12/10/2023 – 12/9/2026
-CWL-4004, Foster Home Reevaluation completed as Renewal
Assessment signed by worker and supervisor 4/9/2024.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as the renewal evaluation
recommendation was completed 4 months after the license
expired.
Conclusion Violation Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
